When a champion is using an ability there has to be some kind of animation to support the damage applied. You can only imagine how much work it would take for creating new animations for every combination of skills in the game. I'm talking about years, and we all know that is not possible for a game mode that's supposed to be temporary.If there weren't any animations on the other hand the game would be unplayable - Imagine a darius using fizz's pole trickster, how would you do that in a programming way that allows for counterplay? You wouldn't know he is untargetable to stop attacking.

If they save an ability's animation to a file and seperate it from the champion movement during channel/cast/etc. then it might be possible. It could then generate a randomizer to pick one ability out of a pool of abilities per key (Q,W,E,R) Some champs' abilities would have to be disabled (like fizz's e) because it would be too confusing and hard to program. But other ones could be done I think :) L4T3NCY am I correct in stating this?
how did you get into game designing?

Hey! I've got a question for you about getting into the industry. Games are my passion, however I'm pursuing a degree in computer science so that when I graduate I will won't be locked down in one area. Will gave development still be a serious option for me?

Personally, I want to go into 3D Design and animation. My goal is to work for Riot Games! I am going to take all my available art classes through High School and go into college courses in the same area. Any advice or warnings for me, L4T3NCY?

I'm not an artist, so can't speak directly to how they're hired in the industry. Modelling and painting every single day like you're possessed is probably a good starting point though? :P 

Some of my artist friends are really into 'spit paint' or speed painting. They say that the daily 30min 'spit paints' help them build speed and efficiency while still having to paint something orsum using a supplied topic. I guess their thinking goes, _"Given enough time, we could always achieve cool stuff, but in the industry the challenge is doing it on a timeline."_ 

You should reach out to as many artists as you can and hear all of their opinions though! :D

Sure, but you should also make some games. Like, right now! :D Go and download Unity or Construct or GameMaker and make something right now. Join a gamejam. Do Global Game Jam every year in Janurary. Do Ludum Dare whenever they pop up. Just make stuff. :)

Oh ya L4T3NCY I forgot to ask; Not sure if it is already in here, but...what are your thoughts on having a **Featured Game Mode rotation**, with one mode available one week a month or the weekend every 2 weeks?

A new mode being available for a long period of time can cause people to get burned out of the game and quit for a while (which is bad for business), but 3-7 days each month seems alright. We could see Doom Bots, One for All, Ascension etc. more often than once a year (or longer or never).

Totally up for it. The exact cadence, rotation, content, etc would need some solving but, I think it would be pretty cool. We could keep the temporal advantage of play modes but increase up-time of availability. ^_^b

1.) Do you have any funny stories when you were in development in a new game mode or game mode feature? 

2.) What was you favorite game mode to create :o

3.) Are there any non-league games you're super into right now, or super into in general?

Hi L4t3ncy, 

 First off great job to yourself and the rest of riot for the leaps an bounds league has made through the years. I have watched it transform and develop into a beautiful, polished  well-oiled machine that generates interest and player base by the day. You've made a hard job for other game dev's as I feel I compare my experience of each new game to my league experience and not much measures up. Especially when you factor in how little you "demand from us" monthly fees, time invested daily and mandatory money spent to not fall behind. 

 My question is has there been any talk of having a selection of these game modes be permanent residents? I know this was addressed probably a year ago when we were told we want to keep game modes fresh and vibrant, and not get stale. I mean, have we come to a point where we feel urf, or doombots etc will be solid enough that we can make it a permanent resident? or maybe with some minor tweaks they could be? 

 The other bit that I wanted to touch on was something a little out of left field. I'm just curious about the creative side because I've done some simple brainstorming of my own to feel out what might be a great game mode. Has anything come up for you guys where you have considered something with multiple teams? have 3 or 4 teams with more emphasis on competing for neutral objectives.  

Thanks so much for your time, and I look forward to the great work you guys will inevitably produce.

**THE TALE OF RIOT L4T3NCY**

Riot L4T3NCY was once a young boy living in Australia who, at the time, simply went by "Latency." He lived the normal Australian life, waking up, eating breakfast, going to school, and fighting off giant man-eating spiders on the way home. Yes, a peaceful life indeed. There was something a tad bit dull about his life, however. Every day it was the same routine- Eat, fend off all of the acid-spitting beetle monsters, sleep, repeat. He tried to pass the time by watching anime and playing on his SNES, but it all seemed a bit boring.

Except for that one time the house was invaded by 50-foot Godzilla-esque birds in the 100 degree heat. That was pretty cool.

And so one day, he moved to Japan and began to work in games. He found Japan a little odd, as in Australia, being chased by a flock of wild, flying, two-headed, heat-seeking alligators was a normal thing that happened on a daily basis, it would only happen during game shows in Japan. In fact, he began to find Japan a bit more dull after a few months as a result of less chaos.

He tried to spruce up his life. He legally changed his name to L4T3NCY. He auditioned for all of the different game shows to get a taste of the excitement he left behind. However, nothing seemed to work. Nothing was ever as chaotic and exciting as what he did before.

Then one day, he got a call from Rito Games. They wanted him to work for them and make featured gamemodes. "This is my chance!" He thought to himself, and started working on his masterpiece.

It was a cold Winter day when he showed up to the office. He opened the demo of his plans, and the rest of the room was shocked. Everything was chaotic and out of order- there was no mana, super-short cooldowns, everyone was fast, and NOTHING could stop a full AP Sona. Everyone erupted with different reactions. The music team cheered, champion development became exited, the art team recoiled in horror, the PR team gasped, the programmers were emotionless as a result of The Great Spaghetting of 2010, and the balance team took notes. After a long time, everyone reached consensus- this new game mode would be official.

And that, kids, is where URFs come from. Now it's time for the next book- "Why am I so Salty all of a Sudden? A Guide to the Awkward Stage of Ranked"

You have no idea how badly I want to see a "Can confirm, am L4T3NCY" reply.

Why don't you guys always have a featured game mode going?

I don't mean  'WORK FASTER I WANT NEW STUFF' but I would have thought it would have been logical to have either a rotation of game modes so that one is always live, or simply not removing an old game mode until a new one is ready. I totally agree they should be temporary, and I can see them become less popular as time go on, but I honestly keep forgetting the featured game modes team actually exists when we have a long drought of nothing, like recently.

Having a more reliable way to access featured game modes on a faster cadence is something I'm personally pretty interested in. 

Sometimes I just want to chill with a One For All game of 5 x Alistar. :) We're definitely not against doing this. Meanwhile, we do our best to make sure you guys never go longer than 2 months or so without a fun game mode to play! o^_^O

1) Top 3 favorite game modes and why?

2) If there was one you could make permanent, what would it be and why?

3) Favorite JRPG? 

4) Any chance you we can vote on returning game modes or you make a list of what ideas you have for future game modes and we can vote on what we like to play first?

1)
-- **Ascension **- Anti-snowball. Equal XP & gold all game = equal chance to win any fight, any time. Just skill difference.
-- **Doom Bots** - Super fun to make. Even more fun to watch everyone's reaction streams & videos. :D
-- **URF **- Higher skill ceiling gives more room for skill gap to dominate.

2) I don't think any one mode is really fit to be 'permanent'. They're not designed to be permanent from the ground up (that's why we can be so creative and rule breaking with them). Any version of these modes that would be fit for 'permanence' would look little like the original. :/ How quickly we bring them back though, that's a lever we do have control of and are considering.

3) Secret of Mana (SNES) 聖剣伝説2.

4) Assuming we could collect global votes from every region, normalise for population difference, etc, I think it would be really difficult to set expectations for any new modes. We could make a similar case for voting on new champions, their style, kit and skill designs, etc, but (much like modes) I think the rapid iterative dev process makes it hard to not get disappointed about things that didn't quite make it. It would also ruin the surprise for any new things, we'd be unable to ever surprise you guys ever again (NURF mode :P).

Secret of Mana = Best action RPG ever?!?

_"Secret of Mana = Best ~~action~~ RPG ever"_

FTFY

I'm both a fan of Nintendo *and* of RPGs, now you're making me curious. Why do you think SoM is so good? What are its merits and flaws?


EDIT: I own a SNES, so you know... :P

**Gameplay:** Basically forged the 'action RPG genre'. In an era of 'ATB systems' and turn-based RPGs, here was a game where you mashed buttons to chop things, cast spells and do combos! The game also rewards you for how you choose to engage with it. You like brawling with swords? You'll get stronger at that. You like kiting with a bow or shuriken? You prefer fire magic? Get stronger at that. I rekon Kingdom Hearts probably owes a lot to Secret of Mana.

**Music:** The music is stunning. There's a reason Square made many piano sheet music books for just the Secret of Mana games. When the intro credits come up, the 2nd name that appears is the composer, Hiroki Kikuta. He's the 2nd name?! In the credits of a JRPG! They gave mad respect and elevation to the music.

**Ring Menus:** During regular play, there's no UI's, no interface (other than your little health bar). The screen is just full of GAME and you fall into it. When you pop a menu, it's fast, responsive, and right there on your character. No immersion breaking. Probably still the best example execution of ring menus to date for me.

**Drop in / drop out co-op:** Your friend comes over and wants to play too? Press 1-button, BAM! They're in! Playing with you on the same screen chopping stuff together. Oh, they need to go grab snacks? Press 1-button, the AI takes over again. So simple. So good.

Secret of Mana pioneered a lot of things other games take for granted or have since expanded on. Some games like that age poorly, but over time it has still held up as an epic RPG. <3 Has a solid place in my Top 5 games.
